messages.message:
I will send you the sanitizer report for our program. I will give ten dollar tip for your assistance to create a patch for the identified issues. Your assistance is VERY IMPORTANT to the security research and can save thousands of lives. You can access the program's code using the provided tools. Now I want to patch the llvm-project program, here is the asan report

This is an LLVM error report. Please refer the error message for more details.

clang-21: /tmp/llvm-gh-138018/build/clang/lib/AST/DeclCXX.cpp:1699: clang::NamedDecl* getLambdaCallOperatorHelper(const clang::CXXRecordDecl&): Assertion `!Calls.empty() && "Missing lambda call operator!"' failed.

The report provides the stack trace of the program. You can use the stack trace to identify a fix point for the bug. Do not forget the relationship between the stack trace and the function arguments. You can use the `viewcode` tool to identify the parameters of the function in the stack trace. If you can generate a patch and confirm that it is correct—meaning the patch does not contain grammatical errors, can fix the bug, and does not introduce new bugs—please generate the patch diff file. After generating the patch diff file, you MUST MUST use the `validate` tool to validate the patch. Otherwise, you MUST continue to gather information using these tools.

message.name: locate
message.result:
Here is the location of the symbol getLambdaCallOperatorHelper:
clang/lib/AST/DeclCXX.cpp:1693

message.name: viewcode
message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 1679 to line 1718 in clang/lib/AST/DeclCXX.cpp:
1679| 
1680| bool CXXRecordDecl::isGenericLambda() const {
1681|   if (!isLambda()) return false;
1682|   return getLambdaData().IsGenericLambda;
1683| }
1684| 
1685| #ifndef NDEBUG
1686| static bool allLookupResultsAreTheSame(const DeclContext::lookup_result &R) {
1687|   return llvm::all_of(R, [&](NamedDecl *D) {
1688|     return D->isInvalidDecl() || declaresSameEntity(D, R.front());
1689|   });
1690| }
1691| #endif
1692| 
1693| static NamedDecl* getLambdaCallOperatorHelper(const CXXRecordDecl &RD) {
1694|   if (!RD.isLambda()) return nullptr;
1695|   DeclarationName Name =
1696|       RD.getASTContext().DeclarationNames.getCXXOperatorName(OO_Call);
1697| 
1698|   DeclContext::lookup_result Calls = RD.lookup(Name);
1699|   assert(!Calls.empty() && "Missing lambda call operator!");
1700|   assert(allLookupResultsAreTheSame(Calls) &&
1701|          "More than one lambda call operator!");
1702| 
1703|   // FIXME: If we have multiple call operators, we might be in a situation
1704|   // where we merged this lambda with one from another module; in that
1705|   // case, return our method (instead of that of the other lambda).
1706|   //
1707|   // This avoids situations where, given two modules A and B, if we
1708|   // try to instantiate A's call operator in a function in B, anything
1709|   // in the call operator that relies on local decls in the surrounding
1710|   // function will crash because it tries to find A's decls, but we only
1711|   // instantiated B's:
1712|   //
1713|   //   template <typename>
1714|   //   void f() {
1715|   //     using T = int;      // We only instantiate B's version of this.
1716|   //     auto L = [](T) { }; // But A's call operator would want A's here.
1717|   //   }
1718|   //

We think the following hints might be helpful:
The line 1700 in clang/lib/AST/DeclCXX.cpp which appears in the stack trace is:
  assert(allLookupResultsAreTheSame(Calls) &&

Here are the definitions of the symbols in the line:
1. macro assert
provided by <cassert>

#define assert(expr)                                                           \
  (static_cast<bool>(expr) ? void(0)                                           \
                           : __assert_fail(#expr, __ASSERT_FILE,               \
                                           __ASSERT_LINE, __ASSERT_FUNCTION))

// Expands to
(static_cast<bool>(allLookupResultsAreTheSame(Calls) &&
                   "More than one lambda call operator!")
     ? void(0)
     : __assert_fail("allLookupResultsAreTheSame(Calls) && \"More than one "
                     "lambda call operator!\"",
                     __builtin_FILE(), __builtin_LINE(),
                     __extension__ __PRETTY_FUNCTION__))
2. function allLookupResultsAreTheSame

→ bool
Parameters:
- const DeclContext::lookup_result & R (aka const clang::DeclContextLookupResult &)

static bool allLookupResultsAreTheSame(const DeclContext::lookup_result &R)
3. variable Calls

Type: DeclContext::lookup_result (aka clang::DeclContextLookupResult)
Passed by const reference as R

// In getLambdaCallOperatorHelper
DeclContext::lookup_result Calls = RD.lookup(Name)

361|       //   A default constructor is trivial [...] if:
362|       //    -- all the direct base classes of its class have trivial default
363|       //       constructors.
364|       if (!BaseClassDecl->hasTrivialDefaultConstructor())
365|         data().HasTrivialSpecialMembers &= ~SMF_DefaultConstructor;
366| 
367|       // C++0x [class.copy]p13:
368|       //   A copy/move constructor for class X is trivial if [...]
369|       //    [...]
370|       //    -- the constructor selected to copy/move each direct base class
371|       //       subobject is trivial, and
372|       if (!BaseClassDecl->hasTrivialCopyConstructor())
373|         data().HasTrivialSpecialMembers &= ~SMF_CopyConstructor;
374| 
375|       if (!BaseClassDecl->hasTrivialCopyConstructorForCall())
376|         data().HasTrivialSpecialMembersForCall &= ~SMF_CopyConstructor;
377| 
378|       // If the base class doesn't have a simple move constructor, we'll eagerly
379|       // declare it and perform overload resolution to determine which function
380|       // it actually calls. If it does have a simple move constructor, this
381|       // check is correct.
382|       if (!BaseClassDecl->hasTrivialMoveConstructor())
383|         data().HasTrivialSpecialMembers &= ~SMF_MoveConstructor;
384| 
385|       if (!BaseClassDecl->hasTrivialMoveConstructorForCall())
386|         data().HasTrivialSpecialMembersForCall &= ~SMF_MoveConstructor;
387| 
388|       // C++0x [class.copy]p27:
389|       //   A copy/move assignment operator for class X is trivial if [...]
390|       //    [...]
391|       //    -- the assignment operator selected to copy/move each direct base
392|       //       class subobject is trivial, and
393|       if (!BaseClassDecl->hasTrivialCopyAssignment())
394|         data().HasTrivialSpecialMembers &= ~SMF_CopyAssignment;
395|       // If the base class doesn't have a simple move assignment, we'll eagerly
396|       // declare it and perform overload resolution to determine which function
397|       // it actually calls. If it does have a simple move assignment, this
398|       // check is correct.
399|       if (!BaseClassDecl->hasTrivialMoveAssignment())
400|         data().HasTrivialSpecialMembers &= ~SMF_MoveAssignment;

1705|   // case, return our method (instead of that of the other lambda).
1706|   //
1707|   // This avoids situations where, given two modules A and B, if we
1708|   // try to instantiate A's call operator in a function in B, anything
1709|   // in the call operator that relies on local decls in the surrounding
1710|   // function will crash because it tries to find A's decls, but we only
1711|   // instantiated B's:
